title: 111_s591
content:
The National Commission on High-Level Radioactive Waste and Spent Nuclear Fuel Establishment Act of 2009 establishes a commission for the purposes of addressing high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel. The commission's composition, duties, powers, staff, compensation, security clearances, reports, and termination are outlined in the Act. The Commission is established to evaluate improvements in the US approach to high-level radioactive waste management if the Yucca Mountain repository is not operational. It will submit a report to Congress with recommendations for managing defense waste, spent nuclear fuel, and commercial radioactive waste. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by various leaders in consultation with relevant committees. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by different leaders in consultation with relevant committees. Appointments include 2 by the minority leader of the House of Representatives, in consultation with committee members, and 1 jointly by the majority leader of the Senate and the Speaker of the House. Qualifications for appointees include restrictions on involvement in high-level radioactive waste activities and employment in certain government entities. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by various leaders, including government officials and tribal representatives. Appointees must be prominent US citizens with expertise in relevant fields. All members must be appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment, with a chairperson appointed under subsection (a)(5). The Commission, consisting of 9 members appointed by government officials and tribal representatives, must have all members appointed within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Chairperson, appointed under subsection (a)(5), will lead the Commission's operations, with meetings called by the Chairperson or a majority of members. Five members constitute a quorum, and vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by government officials and tribal representatives. Five members constitute a quorum, and vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. SEC. 5. DUTIES. The Commission consists of 9 members appointed by government officials and tribal representatives. Five members constitute a quorum, and vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission is tasked with evaluating alternatives to the Federal Government's spent fuel and high-level waste strategies, including transferring responsibility to a Government corporation with necessary authority and funding for storage and management. Cost-sharing options are also considered. The Commission is evaluating alternatives for storage and management of high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel, including cost-sharing options with private industry and establishing centralized interim storage facilities. Research and development for advanced fuel cycle technologies are also being considered. The Commission is evaluating alternatives for storage and management of high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel, including cost-sharing options with private industry and establishing centralized interim storage facilities. Research and development for advanced fuel cycle technologies are also being considered, including reprocessing, transmutation, and recycling technologies that are not vulnerable to weapons proliferation. The Department of Energy would transfer title to spent nuclear fuel inventories at reactor sites, both existing and future, while requiring the transfer of spent nuclear fuel inventories to at-reactor dry casks to ensure public safety and security. The Commission is evaluating alternatives for storage and management of high-level radioactive waste and spent nuclear fuel, including permanent, deep geologic disposal and interim strategies for treatment of defense wastes. Additional management and technological approaches are being considered, such as improved security of spent nuclear fuel storage installations. The Commission will consult with various stakeholders and analyze financial impacts to make recommendations on the disposition of fees charged to nuclear energy ratepayers and the management of spent nuclear fuel. The Commission will recommend the disposition of balances and analyze financial impacts on the government's liability under the Nuclear Waste Policy Act. They will submit a final report to Congress with their findings and recommendations. SEC. 6. POWERS. The Commission has the power to hold hearings, gather evidence, enter into contracts, and obtain information from federal agencies to carry out the duties under this Act. The Commission has the authority to request information, suggestions, estimates, and statistics from federal departments, agencies, and other entities as needed for the Act. Information must be handled and disseminated in accordance with applicable laws and regulations. The Commission can request information from federal agencies for the Act, which must be handled in accordance with applicable laws. The General Services Administration provides administrative support, and other agencies can offer additional services as authorized by law. The Commission can request services, funds, and support from federal agencies as authorized by law. They can also use the United States mails like other government departments. The Federal Advisory Committee Act applies to the Commission, and the Commission can have staff. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint staff without following certain federal employment rules, and their pay cannot exceed a specified level. The staff director and personnel of the Commission are federal employees under specific sections of the United States Code. Members of the Commission are not considered employees. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement, retaining their rights and privileges. The Commission can detail Federal Government employees without reimbursement, allowing them to retain their rights and privileges. The Commission can also procure expert services at rates not exceeding those of a level IV position in the Executive Schedule. SEC. 9. Compensation for Commission members may not exceed the daily equivalent of level IV Executive Schedule pay. Travel expenses are allowed for Commission members while on duty. SEC. 10. Commission members are eligible for security clearances. SEC. 10. Security clearances are provided to Commission members and staff by Federal agencies to access classified information. SEC. 11. REPORTS.

The Commission must release an interim report within 1 year and a final report within 2 years. The final report will include findings, conclusions, recommendations agreed upon by the majority, dissenting opinions with explanations, and consideration of public comments. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the implementation of the Act, with funds available until expended. The Commission's authority terminates 180 days after the final report submission, during which it can conclude its activities and disseminate the final report.
